overview_of_class:
RTVF 378-0 Sec. 20 - Topics in Post Production: Documentary Editing

Course Description & Learning Objectives:
This course is specifically designed to support and inspire students with pre-shot (or nearly shot) documentary material as they edit that material to completion. It will encompass both seminar and lecture-style elements. On the seminar side, students will be expected to take raw documentary footage through several stages of editing deadlines, screenings, and critique in order to complete a short film. Any students who do not have documentary material of their own (encouraged), will be assigned material to work with.

On the lecture side, the course will cover major issues in and approaches to editing a documentary film, ranging from the practical to the theoretical. Major topics we may cover include: Foundational editing theory and history, systems for organizing footage within your project file, editing workflows for single-editor indie films and multi-editor series, cutting observational scenes, using sound/texture to further the story, navigating the editor/director relationship, and the dilemma of cutting for narrative 'truth' versus cutting for emotional clarity and drama. This is NOT a technical training course and a working knowledge of AVID, or Premiere Pro is required. We may go over certain functions from time to time, but a baseline of technical knowledge is assumed. Lynda.com (free for Northwestern students) offers excellent tutorials in all major editing systems if needed.

Evaluation Method:
Editing Exercises and Editing Assignments
Complete Assigned Readings
Participate Fully in Classes and Labs
Written Organizational Assignments
